advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Christmas accounts" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future.... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, software in profusion"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 84'S PARIS-DAKAR RACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A KAYPRO IV IN ACTION SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA <br><br> 8 Kaypro IV and 2 Kaypro 10 were used by the doctors of the Paris-Dakar race 84's edition. The Kaypro IVs were used to store medical information about the 1000 participants. Power was provided by the Mercedes cars through the 12v cigarette lighters. The Kaypro 10s were kept in the "communication" plane during the day, and were used to centralize all the informations in the evening. At the end of the race, and after 12000 km of tracks, there were all running fine ! One of the Kaypro 10 is said to have been thrown out of the plane, mistaken with a common metallic tool box... And it still worked !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The high performance Computer System for practice-oriented applications." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to the <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">PC Leaflets Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1985?)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Power 3000 released in the USA.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://hem.passagen.se/clab/adam/lambda/" target="_blank">Adam's Lambda 8300 page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Once upon a time, the future"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #4 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, SEPTEMBER 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's new. It's the Hit-Bit" <br><br> "The computer according to Sony"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote>In June 1983, IBM was still seeking independant programmers.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666" The envelope please.<br> There's an acceptance letter inside. And a check that could have your name on it. (If we select your program, that is.)<br> But remember. We pick our winners carefully... </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISPLAY SIZE ARGUMENT CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Osborne 1 was the major competitor of the KAYCOMP in the portable computers field.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> POWER... IS EXPENSIVE!</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Megabyte Micro was a special version of the Imsai made with 16 x 64 KB RAM boards (Imsai just introduced this card) and a control board called Intelligent Memory Manager. A mapping configurator allowed each user to use its own protected RAM area. <br><br> Prices :<br><br> 64 KB RAM board Kit: <b>$2599</b>, assembled: <b>$3899</b><br> Intelligent Memory Manager board: <b>$299</b>, assembled: <b>$399</b><br><br> To note: in 1977, 1 MB RAM costed... $62384!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://mayura.jp/blog" target="_blank">Mayura Labo</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: Football (soccer), Handball, Hockey, Tennis, Car race
computer.coprocessor: Ball angle, Paddle size, Ball speed, Power on/off, Reset score, Sound on/off
computer.description:
The main feature of this pong is of course its car racing game! Few systems offered this at the time, so it was a strong commercial advantage.
We have not been able to open the system yet, so we don't know which chip it uses. It could be the F4301 from Omnetics or the AY-3-8603 from General Instruments. Can anyone confirm?
computer.language: Football (soccer), Handball, Hockey, Tennis, Car race
computer.name: Tele-Play SR
